user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSysAddFixedMap:
```c
int32 OS_FileSysAddFixedMap(osal_id_t *filesys_id, const char *phys_path, const char *virt_path)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *filesys;
    int32                         return_code;
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    const char *                  dev_name;

    /*
     * Validate inputs
     */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(filesys_id);
    OS_CHECK_STRING(phys_path, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt), OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG);
    OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(virt_path);

    /*
     * Generate a dev name by taking the basename of the phys_path.
     */
    dev_name = strrchr(phys_path, '/');
    if (dev_name == NULL)
    {
        dev_name = phys_path;
    }
    else
    {
        ++dev_name;
    }

    if (memchr(dev_name, 0, sizeof(filesys->volume_name)) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, dev_name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        filesys = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, token);

        /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
        OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, filesys, device_name, dev_name);

        strncpy(filesys->volume_name, dev_name, sizeof(filesys->volume_name) - 1);
        strncpy(filesys->system_mountpt, phys_path, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt) - 1);
        strncpy(filesys->virtual_mountpt, virt_path, sizeof(filesys->virtual_mountpt) - 1);

        /*
         * mark the entry that it is a fixed disk
         */
        filesys->fstype = OS_FILESYS_TYPE_FS_BASED;
        filesys->flags  = OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_FIXED;

        /*
         * The "mount" implementation is required as it will
         * create the mountpoint if it does not already exist
         */
        return_code = OS_FileSysStartVolume_Impl(&token);

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            filesys->flags |= OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_READY;
            return_code = OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl(&token);
        }

        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /*
             * mark the entry that it is a fixed disk
             */
            filesys->flags |= OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_SYSTEM | OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL;
        }

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, filesys_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileSysAddFixedMap:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_STRING(str, maxlen, errcode) do{OS_CHECK_POINTER(str);LENGTHCHECK(str,maxlen,errcode);}while(0)
...
#define OS_CHECK_PATHNAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_PATH_LEN,OS_FS_ERR_PATH_TOO_LONG)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Reasoning:
- The function parameters are: osal_id_t *filesys_id, const char *phys_path, const char *virt_path.
- There are no assignments to any of these parameter variables (no statements like filesys_id = ..., phys_path = ..., or virt_path = ...). The local pointer dev_name is declared and modified, but it is a separate local variable, not a parameter.
- The object referred to by filesys_id may be updated via calls that take filesys_id (for example OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, filesys_id)); modifying the object pointed to is permitted by the rule.
- phys_path and virt_path are const char *, and the code only reads from them (strrchr, strncpy), it does not attempt to modify the characters they point to nor reassign the parameter pointers.
- The macros used (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_STRING, OS_CHECK_PATHNAME) perform checks and do not reassign the parameter pointers.

Therefore there are no fragments in this function that violate Rule 17.8 (modifying a function parameter or reassigning a pointer parameter).
